So I want to thank everyone for
inviting me here to this event.
It's my first time to Boston.
It's my first time to Harvard.

I can't believe I'm
here, in that it's

one of these huge schools,
right, in the world,

and I'm going to be speaking to
you about a group of women who

have been vilified,
erased, and ignored

for the kinds of
transformations they're

thinking about when we think
about business and society.
And this is the Banker Ladies.

They're going to
teach us about love.

They're going to talk
about citational justice.

And so I'm learning
as a scholar how

to do the work that I
need to do to make sure

that we're changing the
ways in which we live.

So I've been writing for
the better part of a decade

on economic
development that goes
outside of the Western world.

There are scholars and
business schools, economists,

all kinds of political
economists thinking

about development and
economics in new ways

so we can structure development
and the ways in which we

do business very different so
this term inclusive isn't just

window dressing,
but we're really

tackling the structural
inequalities that exist.

What I'm going to speak to
you a little bit about--

it might be dry, and I'm going
to try and race with the time

so we catch up and
we stay orderly--

so what I'm going to speak about
is the book that I'm currently

working on, which is
The Banker Ladies--

The Vanguards of the
Solidarity Economies.

I'm still working
on my revisions.

It feels like I've been working
with peer review for four
years.

But I like to situate myself
as a feminist and an economist,

and a political economist,
specifically, looking at I

come from Caribbean immigrants
who migrated first to New York

City, where I was
born, and then I
was raised in Toronto, Canada.
Most of my life was precarious.

We crisscrossed
around the cities.

So I'm very sort of
attuned to the women
that I'm working with.
They're tough as nails.

And I think when you grow
up in that kind of filth,
you become like that.

And for 15 years,
it's no mistake

that I had to dedicate my life's
work to trying to figure out

what financial access
and economic opportunity
actually means.

And I worked for
a number of years

doing that, mostly in Africa,
parts of the Caribbean,

specifically Haiti, and also
with Lakshmi Ramarajan, who

I want to thank her and
Robin for inviting me.

It's a really good opportunity
to speak with you business

leaders, because I hope you
can help me translate what I'm
going to share with you today.

And I work for this institution
called OIC International out
of Philadelphia, Germantown.

And what they were doing was
trying to co-opt development

aid, African-American founded,
led, and working in Africa,

trying to think about how do
we do economics differently.

And I didn't
realize at the time,

but they were one
of few institutions

that was doing that
kind of work globally.

And what I learned
from African-Americans

was how do we do business
in a more equitable way.

And that's what I'm going
to speak about today.
This whole theme is about--

I can't believe that Harvard
Business School is doing this,

but it's about getting these
tools to humanize economics,
the human economy.

And if Harvard can
have a session here

to do that, how can we trigger
that effect to business schools

and universities around,
particularly in the West?

That's what I'm
going to speak about.

I'm going to speak about this
world system, capitalist system

that the Banker Ladies are
actually pushing up against,

because equity and
diversity means zero

if you're still working through
a racial capitalist system.

And it's not about
the reforming,

it's actually about
the transformation

to create democracy
within the businesses we
want to see in our planet.

So the system that I'm
going to speak about

are the Rotating Savings
and Credit Associations.
I call them, for short, ROSCAs.

How many people have heard of
the term, these names, Sousou,
Patna, Box Hand?
Yeah, OK, good.
There's a few on this side.

Any of these names
resonate with you?

These are names from
the African diaspora.

ROSCAs is actually
an academic term

to explain this
global phenomenon,

but people use their
local vernacular

to explain the kind of informal
cooperative money systems

that they are using
below the surface.
But these names are so global.

Indians have "chit-funds",
Sri Lankans [have] "chitu",

Indonesians have "arisan",
Chinese have "hui".

So it goes beyond
the African diaspora.

I'm fixated on the
African diaspora.

I'm a child of that
community, so that's
what I'm trying to amplify.

And we're trying to figure
out what kind of theory
makes sense.

In Canada, Europe,
America, they use

the term the social
economy, often

seeing people of color, Blacks
as on the receiving end of aid.

But as we said, we've got to
change the deficit framing

to one of celebrity
because there

are a lot of heroes
and people who

are protagonists in terms of
changing the ways in which we
do things.

We're not just
waiting on handouts.

We're actually a part of the
social economy, solidarity

economy, building
things differently.

And that's what the women
who organize these ROSCAs

are called the Banker Ladies,
a name they call themselves.
I didn't give it to them.

And they are the
chief organizers

of these informal
cooperative institutions

who are trying to
find theory, who

are trying to correct
the citational blindness
and exclusion that's happening.

So everyone here has
a lot of homework

to do because there
is an abundance

of Black political
economy that can

be useful in business
schools, but people
aren't citing those names.

We decolonize syllabi
and our writings,

but we're not actually
doing the homework

of citing these Black scholars,
Indigenous scholars who

are writing on economics
and political economy

in ways that speak to the lived
experience of the people we
want to learn from.

And my work is building on
Jessica Gordon Nembhard,

an economist, political
economist at CUNY

who's writing about
the collective courage

of African-Americans in
practice and thought of how we
build cooperative institutions.

A story that was completely
obliterated and hidden

because it was too dangerous
to expose, actually.

Because what we want to do
is preserve a certain model
of business, right?

We don't want to know that we
can have membership-owned types
of firms.

My work relies a
lot on the thinking

of folks like Marcus
Garvey mainly because he

had the foresight to think
about new types of businesses,

especially under
extreme exclusion.

And then a more
obscured economist

by the name of CY Thomas,
who definitely mentored me,

speaks to this idea
of convergence theory.

Why don't we focus on local
consumption needs, the things

that we need at the
grassroots, and do away

with all this world
system extractive kinds
of economic systems?

Because when you play
with them to do diversity,

we're always amazed
that this stuff is not
working in allyship.
Well, because look at the roots.

Eric Williams wrote a book
called "Capitalism and Slavery"

and how it was bound up
in a very immoral origin.

Why do we want to continue
associating with that?

So that's the
literature that I use

because it needs to reflect on
the experience of these women

who are being constantly
violated in the arenas

that I work in, which
is the Caribbean and two

big cities in Canada,
Toronto and Montreal,

where we see the largest
numbers of Black and African
or Caribbean Canadians.
And you see the numbers.

It looks small, 400, but those
are the chief banker ladies.

Those are the ladies that are
organizing these cooperatives
that I'm speaking to solely.

There are lots of stakeholders,
but this is the group

that I want to
zero in for my book

because I think what
they have to say

are these words of wisdom of how
we correct economic exclusion.

Multiply that number by at
least a factor of 30, maybe 40.

And that's modest
because in Haiti

these cooperative institutions
are upwards of 100 or 200,
right?

I met a woman in Canada who
has a Janji cooperative, money
cooperative.

She had 1,000 members across
Canada, so that's the extreme.

This stuff is
happening right now.

In Boston, I'm going
to meet someone

on Saturday who runs
a MoZiki bank here
in Boston, Congolese American.

Has about 50 or 60
members at any given time.

There's a divergence when
I study women of the South

and then those
situated in the North.

The story in Canada has been
one to ignore and pretend

we don't see, the collectivity
by these Black Canadian women

when they want to
mitigate the oppression

within financial systems and
self-fund their own projects.

So I'm trying to interfere
with Canada's story

on the social economy and
rightly so, particularly

because we have a history,
a legacy of cooperation

from the Desjardin Movement
to our Antigonish Movement.

But we just don't want
to hear about the ROSCA

phenomenon, "Susu",
"box hand", "chit",
and all these kind of things.
It's inconvenient, I think.

And so what these women have
in common across the Caribbean

in Canada is that these are
cherished cooperative systems.

They see themselves as members
participating, structuring

debate, organizing, and pooling
funds on a fixed period.

Everyone understands the
governance structure.

We can say informal,
but there are actually

very formalized structural
and governance arrangements

taking place below the surface
for a variety of reasons.

I think many of you may have
read "Portfolios of the Poor."

It's a book that got a lot
of fanfare, rightly so.

It interviewed
hundreds of people

mostly in the global
South to learn

about the financial diaries
of low-income people.

Over and over again,
these ROSCA systems
were continually very important.

So it amazes me when we
get all these books written

on economic inclusion,
and we're never,

ever thinking about the
cooperative institutions

that people in these communities
are building ground up.

In fact, these systems are
so admired in the Caribbean

that elite bankers from Canadian
banks to Jamaican or Haitian

will actually copy
these ROSCA systems.

Meaning that they'll create
product lines because they know

the majority of their
citizens use these localized
cooperative systems.

It's a way of expanding
their market niche.

Mummy here in
Grenada, and the book

is going to be littered with
all kinds of testimonials.

Of course, we're going to
go through the risks of what
these ROSCA systems look like.

I don't have enough
time to do that today,

but what I'm trying
to do is make the case

and show you why these ROSCA
are so valued and defended
by the women who use them.

Mummy is here telling you
-- "it's the underlining

importance --" She's a
spice trader in Grenada.

"The underlining importance of
these ROSCA or "Susu" systems
is trust."

These are not educated
women in a formal sense,

but they have
years of experience

as being entrepreneurs
and businesswomen

tending to their own needs,
assisting community out

of love and reciprocity, but not
focused on the profit motive.

They're looking at cooperation
and member participation.

In the Caribbean, it's
not a glorious story.

There's all kinds of inequities
and exclusions occurring.

There's anti-Black racism
in certain contexts.

But these systems create
a way out for people

when formal or targeted
poverty alleviation programs
just don't work.

People have their
"Susu" or "Box-hand"

systems to assist them to meet
their livelihood needs but also

to repair the harms that are
happening in society that you

can't get through mainstream
systems because the very root

of it has been corrupt or
detrimental to their own
health.

Just as the banker ladies
in Jamaica, the Caribbean,

have been doing a
lot of work in terms

of dealing with politicized
financing issues, in Canada,
the story is very different.

I expected to see
something else because it's

such a country that prides
its cooperative traditions.

But in fact the banker
ladies of Canada

has been the hardest, most
humbling piece of work
I have done as an academic.

To see these women in completely
vulnerable situations.

And I'm speaking
life-or-death situation,
and this is Toronto the good.
Right?
Women are being stigmatized.
They are being labeled gamblers.

They're being labeled
as drug mules,

as terrorists, particularly
from the Somali and Jamaican
communities.

I mean, I'm often an
expert witness for cases

because people don't
understand what

mutual aid, and ROSCAs,
and informal cooperative
institutions are.

These women themselves
here will tell you they
know they're being stigmatized.

They know the work
that they are doing

is radical because
they're fighting
intense forms of oppression.

But they're not trying to
be on anyone's victim list

because they are going to
create and build things

that many of us
don't even comprehend

what they're trying to do
because these have ancestral
legacies.
Right?

I'm going to let
them speak to you.

- But also so if you
have it in your country,
you still bring it.

So when you go, you meet
people from your country.

You say, oh, you
remember "Susu".
They say yes.

You remember when we
used to read back home?
So why don't we bring it back?

- So we developed
a structure that

was slightly different than the
one that my mom and her friends
used.

- And you taught me help,
and we have a group of 10
of women to $200.
I give it $2,000.
- That makes me independent.

I feel empower to
have something.

So that's The
Banker Ladies film.

I'm by no means creative, but
when I do my community work,

these women were like, all these
books that you write, useless,
zero.
[LAUGHTER]

You need to change
mindset, and we're
going to help you do that.

I said, well, then you're
going to star in this film.
And so this is open access.

It's been funded by the
Canadian government.
It's a 20-minute documentary.
Get the word out.

The Banker Ladies,
they're really teaching us

about what economic
cooperation can be
and actually is in our world.

So we're dealing in an
era of anti-Black racism.
Everyone's all twisted up.

They can't quite figure
out how do we undo this.

But the banker ladies
have been hard at work
for centuries doing this work.

In the West,
outside of the West.

They've just been dealing
with structural inequality.

That's what they've
been dealing with.

But how now do we include
them in our community

economic development programs
that are often subsidized?
No, we're not doing that.

We actually expect Black
women who are marginalized,

low-income, working in
all these hero-type jobs

to receive their
minimum wage pay

and still do the civil
society building work
to keep our country strong.
And this is happening in Canada.
It's happening in Europe.
It's happening in the US, right?

My work is now thinking, why are
we not remunerated these women?

This is community
economic development
work that they're doing.

They're building politicized,
engaged citizens.

The young generation
here, Munira Abukar

and Andria Barrett, are
two of these women, hail

from Somali and
Jamaican backgrounds,
Canadians as Canadians can be.

They're using the funds
from these ROSCA systems

to assist them so that they
can run for political office.

Imagine that, informal
institutions using

the money that are deemed
illegal to help them

run for political office so that
they can bring social justice
change.
So I'm learning.

As an academic, tenured,
holding a Canada Research Chair,

I still don't even
know what I'm doing.

But what I do know,
that I am a scribe

for these women because they're
actually teaching us lessons

about how to be
better humans, how

to understand that
money is just a part.

We're only here
for a small while.

So why don't we figure
out how we prioritize
peoples' needs first?

And then we'll figure out how we
develop our communities, right?

And don't assume that the
knowledge isn't there.
It's always there.

And so what Fardowsa
is telling you here,

Somali-born, is that people
might look at this Hagbad bank

as something strange and
different, but it's not.
It's about social well-being.

It's just not an economic
financial transaction.

It's about curing the harms
that people have endured

in the marketplace,
creating a forum for people

to become engaged citizens
and uplift one another.
That's the human economy.

That's how we humanize
economics, right?

That's thinking about
social provisioning, right?

It goes beyond just how much
is in our bank account, right?

So what they're trying to do is
teach us, teach us these tools,

but we're not seeing
them, particularly
in the Canadian context.

And what we do know
is that we don't
have to start from scratch.
Development assistance.

I teach in global
development at U of T.

We're always teaching
about there's always

this idea that it goes one way,
from the North to the South.
No, no.

We need to now ask
Kerala, India how

they were managed to do
the Kundumbashree system

and get the political buy-in
to bring in low-caste women

to participate in
development plans.

Ghana has a
centuries-old Susu system

that has premier
economists are thinking

through part of its
system to make it
a part of their formal system.
Not all of it.

They have applied a
very pragmatic approach
because informality is OK.

And finally, South
Africa is like,

we need to do training
and capacity building

to have a national
stockpile system

and to make people
recognize that this

is a part of your ecosystem
for financial goods.
Right?

And so finally, I leave
you here with this.

These are women that I have
been working with for years.

And they have changed me as an
academic in a fundamental way

because I see the
stressors of life.

I know the risks
that they endure,

and the harms with
police raids continually

is happening in
low-income communities

across the Americas, even
in my own city of Toronto.

And we last year formed the
Banker Ladies Council of 2022.

And now I take a back
seat, and they're

educating the Canadian
public about what

it means to start and create
a ROSCA system not just
for Black folk in the Americas.

But we're now finding
Iranian women are coming out
of the woodworks.

Latinas are like,
hey, we do "tandas".

So we're finding that
this is a system.

Canadian women are
like, I'm low-income.
I'm White.
How can I join this group?

This is a system
that we're thinking

for all women who want to
think put back the reciprocity

and trust in the ways in
which we organize finance
in our communities.

Most days, I'm at
Toronto, University
of Toronto Scarborough.
That's where I spend my days.

I'm a part of the Diverse
Solidarity Economies

collective, a group
of-- you can Google

it-- a group of feminist
economists who are really

thinking about how we
decolonize economics

or make it more plural, as
the way we like to say it.
You can email me.
Contact me any which way.
I'd like it.
Thanks.
Blessings.
